abstract.p: TV Sports column discusses ABC hiring Dennis Miller as broadcaster on Monday Night Football; photo (M)

block.p: Hello again, everyone, this is Howard Cosell speaking of sports.
Crude, vulgar, obnoxious, truculent, verbose, condescending, a wiseacre.
Hello again, everyone, this is Howard Cosell speaking of sports.
Crude, vulgar, obnoxious, truculent, verbose, condescending, a wiseacre.
There is no question that Dennis Miller is all of these things.
Much has been written by print reporters, that seedy lot of hangers-on, about Miller, in essence, replacing me on ABC's ''Monday Night Football.''

What a tribute to my palpable impact and how right I was for my times that I have been irreplaceable for 16 seasons. Would that young Dennis handle my halftime highlights, a historic demonstration of ad-libbing proficiency.

Young Dennis is quite the mischievous monkey on his weekly HBO program. I watched it Friday night and I have rarely in my illustrious career, with my full knowledge of constitutional law, listened to somebody in greater need of a First Amendment defense lawyer. I don't blush easily, but young Dennis articulated vulgarities 18 times in a mere 30 minutes. Young Dennis informed viewers that ''golly'' will be his ''Monday Night'' code for a famous epithet.
Not even the Danderoo ever took such reckless verbal risks.

I have not been so appalled -- so horrified, so assaulted -- since Nov. 26, 1982 -- the Houston Astrodome -- when Larry Holmes brutalized -- even destroyed -- a defenseless and desperately untalented Randall (Tex) Cobb for 12 dehumanizing rounds.

It is unsurprising to this reporter that Don Ohlmeyer, a man I greatly respect, turned to young Dennis to save ''Monday Night Football.'' But he doubtlessly got the idea from yours truly: in 1985, I wrote, with characteristic perspicacity, that the show needed a star, like Bill Cosby.
We're dealing with football, an entertainment, not the canonization of a saint. I believe young Dennis and I share much, yet not enough. To his detriment.

We each suffer from bad hair. For no apparent reason, he calls attention to his slovenly tresses by nervously running his hand through them. I dared not touch what I had, lest it move into unsuitable and unstylish hairlines.

Young Dennis and I are alumni of ''Saturday Night Live.'' My version, on ABC, started before NBC's, yet it lasted but 22 weeks. You are indisputably aware of its auspicious start: the American debut of the Bay City Rollers.

When I appeared as a guest on the NBC show, I dressed up as a relative of Ed Grimley, the transcendent nerd created by Martin Short. Dennis Miller merely emceed ''Weekend Update'' on that program, replacing, in essence, Chevy Chase.
I, of course, never replaced anyone.
I was, and continue to be, an original.
To his credit, this young scamp works assiduously at being unlikable.
I never toiled at it, such a skill coming naturally.
He employs words like weaponry as I wielded words and thoughts like the jabs Ali threw before the United States government stripped him of his right to work.

Young Dennis's intelligence is eclectic, even catholic, like mine. I can envision him hosting a show like my ''Speaking of Everything.'' His potty-mouthed show on Friday ranged from commentary on Bill Gates and the execution of the convicted Texas murderer Gary Graham to security leaks at Los Alamos.
I confess to a modicum of shame at laughing when he remarked, ''It's always nice to know the doomsday machine is hooked up to a Clapper.''

I also confess that this lad is quite the communicator. Like me, he possesses a rapport with young people, the type of skill that told me I was the right person to report to America that John Lennon had been assassinated.

Yet, as someone for whom ''Monday Night'' is a distant and bad memory, I am concerned about whether young Dennis's penchant for baroque similes will work for an audience weaned on pedestrian analyses of X's and O's and an overdependence on scribbling with the Telestrator.

Can a tackle by the insouciant defensive end Bruce Smith, long of the Buffalo Bills, now with the suddenly renascent Washington Redskins, be rightly compared to a ''choice between walking and hitching a ride with a bisexual trucker''? Will there be credibility to young Dennis describing the muddied nose of an offensive tackle as if it had ''inhaled Bob Marley feet first''?

In the booth with Alfalfa Michaels, with whom I once called ''Monday Night Baseball,'' and Dan Fouts -- the newest recruit of manifest ordinariness from the Jockocracy, a substratum of ex-jocks and ex-coaches that does not respect the training required to be an effective broadcaster -- Miller will divide viewers between those who admire and those who abhor him.
I have considerable expertise in this field, having once been voted the most loved and hated sportscaster, simultaneously, in a TV Guide poll.

I made ''Monday Night.'' I was the one who gave it moment. Those who succeeded me -- Joe Willie Namath, The Juice, Dan Dierdorf, Boomer Esiason -- had their moments, too, but they occurred during the time of William of Orange.

Yet I harbor some hope for young Dennis. He has none of my experience, yet if he can make viewers hate him, and organize screen-bashing keg parties to protest his most grotesque utterances, ratings will ascend accordingly.
Many years ago, Jim Brown described Howard Cosell as a warrior, whose career could be measured by the caliber of his enemies.
Young Dennis has much to shoot for.
This is Howard Cosell.
